content: pasted image I am getting the message that the system canot find the path specified . Moreover I am not able to move into (zulip-venv)

hi @Minerva Panda I am working with getting the dev-env up for windows too ! might be we can help each other. From your screenshot it was clear that you haven't started the provisioning . You can do that by doing vagrant provision before ssh-ing into the vagrant box or have a look at https://zulip.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev-env-first-time-contributors.html#step-2-get-zulip-code . Please read those additional steps and let me know if it was helpful !

==> default: 0 upgraded, 0 newly installed, 0 to remove and 0 not upgraded.
==> default: sudo: unable to execute ./scripts/lib/setup-apt-repo: No such file or directory
==> default: + sudo ./scripts/lib/setup-apt-repo
==> default: Traceback (most recent call last):
==> default: File "/srv/zulip/tools/provision.py", line 221, in <module>
==> default:
==> default: sys.exit(main())
==> default: File "/srv/zulip/tools/provision.py", line 127, in main
==> default:
==> default: run(["sudo", "./scripts/lib/setup-apt-repo"])
==> default: File "/srv/zulip/scripts/lib/zulip_tools.py", line 93, in run
==> default:
==> default: raise subprocess.CalledProcessError(rc, args) # type: ignore # https://github.com/python/typeshed/pull/329
==> default: subprocess
==> default: .
==> default: CalledProcessError
==> default: :
==> default: Command '['sudo', './scripts/lib/setup-apt-repo']' returned non-zero exit status 1
The SSH command responded with a non-zero exit status. Vagrant
assumes that this means the command failed. The output for this command
should be in the log above. Please read the output to determine what
went wrong.
This is the error I am getting even after vagrant provision . what should i do ?
edit /srv/zulip/toots/provision.py line 127 i.e. changerun(["sudo", "./scripts/lib/setup-apt-repo"]) to run(["sudo", "scripts/lib/setup-apt-repo"]) .

In addition @Minerva Panda I would suggest from next time onwards whenever a particular command fails with Subprocess error(CalledProcessor error), I would suggest running a python IDE and importing the subprocess module and then compiling the failed command as subprocess.Popen(<syntax of failed process>) because this is what the run command in /srv/zulip/scripts/lib/zulip_toots.py is trying to do .
@Tim Abbott @Steve Howell @Sumana Harihareswara Can't we edit the raise error line in scripts/lib/zulip_tools.py to give a better debug message.(just a suggestion!)
def run(args, **kwargs): # type: (Sequence[str], **Any) -> int # Output what we're doing in the `set -x` style print("+ %s" % (" ".join(args))) print(args, **kwargs) process = subprocess.Popen(args, **kwargs) rc = process.wait() if rc: raise subprocess.CalledProcessError(rc, args) # type: ignore # https://github.com/python/typeshed/pull/329 return 0
I like the idea of having a wrapper function.
@Diptanshu Jamgade yeah that's a good idea, I'd definitely take a patch to make run print a better error message.
@Tim Abbott and @Steve Howell thank you so much ! the patch is definitely on its way !

@Tim Abbott Do I need to do any sort of test-clearance for the above patch ! Also, I would like to know anything special feature we would like in the patch before I submit ! @Steve Howell Any specific suggestions ?
I think for a run() wrapper, it is probably sufficient to test it manually.

In the present version a raise subprocess.CalledProcessorError is raised for every exception. The scrapper I wrote first outputs the exception faced by the child processsubprocess.Popen() and then to interrupt the further execution I call the raise subprocess.CalledProcessorError . Any alternative to this approach of will this meet our necessity ?

I think we may also want the wrapper to have some kind of messaging that says something like "Often, provision will fail due to transient errors, so your best course of action, after copying/pasting the traceback above to hastebin, is to simply try running it again." We should do that as a separate commit, though, and it doesn't need to hold up your original effort.

I am pretty comfortable with working further in this direction as I have basic idea of how the process is executing. Apart from the next commit you suggested, would there be anything else for the wrapper . I think a pull request would give you a better idea of how the wrapper is outputting error ! Thank you for suggestions @Steve Howell

If you are interested in pushing this concept a little further, I think we could take advantage of the run() method to provide a little some timing data about how long subprocesses take to run when people do provisioning, so we can see what the bottlenecks are on different platforms. We'll probably want to brainstorm a bit on that with @Tim Abbott before doing too much work there.

@Steve Howell http://hastebin.com/suvugoyato.rb Could you please have a look at this ? Apart from the error i would like to highlight how the wrapper is outputting the error. In that hastebin you could make out Exacterror>>.............<<. That is the child process error and the following suprocess error is just to interrupt. I just posted this here to show how my error looks to be (after applyng the wrapper for run()). Rest about the error i face in provisioning can be discussed in ```windows````.
The output looks good. I think you want a space between "Exact" and "error", but otherwise it seems like pretty clear output to me, and this should be a big help!

@Steve Howell As per our discussion here, could you please ellaborate to me about the error my pull request is facing ! https://github.com/zulip/zulip/pull/1902/commits
Thank you !
Please look at the Travis output.
Does a space after # for a comment in python matter ? I was unaware about it !
It's a style thing.

I installed vagrant and was starting the dev env when I encounter this
http://hastebin.com/xigubeyizi.php
Should I proceed anyways? If not, how could I rectify the last error?
I read something about removing the 'Defaults requiretty' from your sudoers file. Can't find 'Defaults requiretty' in my sudoers file though..

I don't know much about the vagrant zulip environment, but sudoers can be changed as follows:
search for requiretty

You can add lines like the following to your sudoers file

Defaults: %groupname !requiretty
Defaults: username !requiretty
so if the user is vagrant, you can add Defaults: vagrant !requiretty to your sudoers file
the above assumes that your issue is a sudoers tty issue
@Poornima Haridas I'm not sure about sudoers, but I noticed the last line of your hastbin `redir is not installed or is not accessible on the PATH.`
which amkes me think you have have redir installed, which is a prerequisit.
http://zulip.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev-env-first-time-contributors.html#ubuntu
@Christie Koehler I did try to install redir, but it keeps showing unable to locate package :/

http://hastebin.com/uxaduxific.sql
This is what happens so I installed packages one by one and the last 2 dont install
@Poornima Haridas what version of Ubuntu are you using?
I'm using 16.04
@Poornima Haridas Have you updated your package info recently? sudo apt-get update?
Yep. Did that before I started and again today when I tried again
@Poornima Haridas Hmm. I see from here that redir is part of official packages. http://packages.ubuntu.com/xenial/redir
@Poornima Haridas perhaps your apt isn't configured to search all of the official repositories? What does your /etc/apt/sources.list look like?
http://hastebin.com/gigoyalibo.coffeescript
@Poornima Haridas Interesting, apt isn't configured to use the official sources
Oh ok
How can I configure it to use it then?
@Poornima Haridas comment out the lines with ftp.iitm.ac.in
Done. I can try again now?
no, you need to add entries to replace those
i am trying to get you non-US specific ur.s
urls
But the ftp.iitm.ac.n was non-US right?
yes, but those servers didn't have the packages you need
I don't think they are official ubuntu packages servers. they look like a mirror
which is common, and usually not a problem
Oh alright..
but for some reason they are missing redir and maybe other things
in my /etc/apt/sources.list, I have:
I had to change it way before I updated to 16.04 because odf some other package installation problem

deb http://us.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ xenial universe
deb http://us.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ xenial multiverse
deb http://us.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ xenial-updates multiverse
```
@Poornima Haridas oh! do you recall what it was before you changed it?

Nope :/
Only that it was a US server
I'll share my whole sources.list
and then I have to go into a meeting, but will check in with you when I'm done
So I should replace it with mine?
http://hastebin.com/sulijegami.nginx
Should I try to select the best server option and see if that works, from the software&Updates?
Yes, I would try going back to the default settings
because we know redir and cgroup packages are available on ubuntu servers
Cool. I'll try both then. Replace with your sources.list and changing the server
Wait would they be the same if I change with your sources.list?
@Poornima Haridas I'm not sure if it would be the same. make a back up of your /etc/apt/sources.list before you make any changes just in case.

Yep. Did that :)
I'll get on with that then!
after you make changes to the sources
and do apt get update
Cool!
you can see if the package is available BEFORE you try to install anything
with
let me remember...
apt-cache search redir I think?
or apt-cache show redir
okay, to me meeting
be back later
thanks! (Y)

Ok the replacement works. And apt-cache show redir shows version 2.2.1-13.
Do tell me once you are back if I can proceed with starting up the dev env or I need to start from some other step of the set-up instructions :)
oh, that's great!
I'm still in my meeting, but wanted to answer you

I would make sure the other prerequisites are installed:

sudo apt-get install build-essential git ruby lxc lxc-templates cgroup-lite redir
vagrant plugin install vagrant-lxc
vagrant lxc sudoers
just to be sure
then try vagrant up again
Okay, done with my meeting.
@Poornima Haridas How are things going?
Just finished vagarant up
*vagrant
Successful! :)
@Christie Koehler Thanks! I can finally get started on my first contribution! :)
@Poornima Haridas that is great news! I'm glad I could help.
One last doubt. Does the server take really long to start?
@Poornima Haridas by 'server', do you mean 'vagrant up' or 'run-dev.py'?
run-dev.py
it starts a few different services so it can take a little while. I should show you messages as it starts each one, though. Are you seeing anything?
Tornado server running

and then lots of lines similar to
2016-10-07 15:00:31,270 INFO Received event: {u'timestamp': 1475866826.994505, u'user_profile_id': 2, u'message_id': 7}
ends with 2016-10-07 15:10:26,917 INFO Tornado removed 0 idle event queues owned by 0 users in 0.000s. Now 0 active queues, 0 handlers, latest ID 0

Oh wait! This means it's running...
Silly me :/
So do I keep this terminal open until the end of my session?
yep :)
Thanks! :)
@Poornima Haridas yes, and the output in that terminal can help you while you're developing, too

Cool! :)
*finally looks into a first contribution :D
Hi @Tim Abbott (MIT)
My vagant up is showing something like that

==> default: Checking if box 'fgrehm/trusty64-lxc' is up to date...
Vagrant cannot forward the specified ports on this VM, since they
would collide with some other application that is already listening
on these ports. The forwarded port to 9991 is already in use
on the host machine.

To fix this, modify your current project's Vagrantfile to use another
port. Example, where '1234' would be replaced by a unique host port:

  config.vm.network :forwarded_port, guest: 9991, host: 1234

Sometimes, Vagrant will attempt to auto-correct this for you. In this
case, Vagrant was unable to. This is usually because the guest machine
is in a state which doesn't allow modifying port forwarding. You could
try 'vagrant reload' (equivalent of running a halt followed by an up)
so vagrant can attempt to auto-correct this upon booting. Be warned
that any unsaved work might be lost.
Does vagrant reload as suggested by that error message help?
vagrant reload is showing same error message

I gotta run, but depending on what OS you're running, you should be able to just find the process listening on that port and kill it (google should be able to find you docs for this).

If you don't want to figure out how to do that, rebooting the host will almost certainly make the problem go away.

@sinwar are you running off Zulip master, or has it been a few days since you checked out the master branch and ran git pull upstream master?
nope I didn't pull @Sumana Harihareswara
@sinwar when you run git log what is the date of the most recent commit?
(when you run that in the directory that holds the Zulip repository on your local computer)
oct 6

@sinwar I think it's worth it for you to run

git checkout master && git pull upstream master && git push origin master
[although the specific commit I wanted to make sure you had, b4108f7a5fe924da26bcd2561dde324ca48ce26f , was merged a few days before 6 October, so that won't affect the outcome of this]

I have to head away from the computer for much of the evening but @sinwar if you read the last few days' worth of messages here, in development help, installation help, provision, and in GitHub issues around installation and provisioning, those might help you too
Sorry I don't have more tips -- hope others do!
@sinwar also it's worth checking the recent pull requests in zulip/zulip which have some improvements to documentation and troubleshooting tips
like, do you have enough RAM?
good luck

You have to use zulipdev@<your_username>.zulipdev.org:9991
or <your_username>@zulipde.org:9991

@Aaron Joyce you certainly can use it inside vagrant (or any other vm provider), just need to forward the web ports
